Road identification is one of my focus areas, so some basic advice:
- It sounds like it has a median. Note the major foliage and its spacing. If you were to look at it top-down from a satellite, how would it look?
- Note every single sign, even the ones that are facing the other way. Most road signs all have a shape tied to their function. You may be able to discern specific things about the location even without knowing what the signs say. 
- Every feature of a roadway is intentional. Even if the purpose for a feature is out-of-frame, you can make educated guesses on what's not visible. For example, a curb cut four lanes wide is typically for a busy parking lot. If the paint on the edges is different in the foreground versus the background, that could indicate a significant road feature like a bridge or overpass.

Hey folks, I recently made a Gemini project working on one of the open questions! We know LLMs are great at coding, so I drafted an MVP for using multiple agents to code Google Earth Engine scripts (started working on this project before MolTBot).

üîó Demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_hWtLnabNxg
üîó Repo: https://github.com/Aryan-Jhaveri/gemini-earthengine-codegenerator

MCGEE is a multi-agent system that writes Google Earth Engine scripts for you. You describe what you want to analyze (deforestation, flood detection, urban growth, etc.) and 4 AI agents collaborate to research the methodology and write the code. Strictly limited to google's gemini SDK and API atm, so pretty closed source mvp.

I think it's a basic project idea with some potential, especially with  Subject Matter Experts' guidance - people who do this stuff day in and day out.

The coding agent is currently limited to whatever URL scraping it can do for API docs, but can be pushed further by model distillation and some fine-tuning to have really nice niche scripts written specifically‚Äîalong with adding some MCP tools to give agents the ability to use their "visual" analysis (LLMs of course can't "see" things per se, or at least how I understand it).

Would love to collaborate if anyone's interested in pushing this further!

Some high value art transactions are linked to Leon Black, the American private equity investor and the former CEO of Apollo Global Management.  For ex. on 23 November 2016 for example Black sold an Alberto Giacometti sculpture from his massive private art collection for $25 million to a trust controlled by Epstein, who by then was already a registered sex offender.  

To help pay for the Giacometti, Epstein had his staff wire $23 million into a Haze Trust account the day before the transaction took place. That money was wired from an account belonging to Southern Trust, which was Epstein‚Äôs main moneymaking company in the Virgin Islands and received a lucrative tax break from the U.S. territory.  (Most of Southern Trust‚Äôs revenue came from the fees Black paid).

Find it here or on podcast platforms under 'Stage Talks with Bellingcat' : https://rss.com/podcasts/bellingcatstagetalk/2507049/

There may be some confusion about how to use the relatively new Soar Atlas platform by `@x4rius`, the author of the first post shared.

The highlighted bounding box is very large....almost 12,300 square kilometers. When you select such a large maritime area, Soar Atlas often offers only lower-resolution imagery.

If we select a similarly sized maritime area off the US East Coast, Soar Atlas indicates that only low-quality 50m/pixel satellite imagery is available‚Äîthe same resolution as `@x4rius` ü§´ alleged satellite spot of US carrier strike group. 

(Note: This does not indicate that there is a secret aircraft carrier off the coast of New York/New Jersey.)

However, when we select a much smaller area (~500 square kilometers) in the same Gulf of Oman/Arabian Sean  region that @x4rius was examining, Soar Atlas offers "Best Quality" 10m/pixel imagery. This demonstrates that higher-resolution imagery is available for that exact area.....you just need to use an appropriately sized bounding box to access it.

Moreover,  50m/pixel resolution is more than adequate to spot an aircraft carrier‚Äîso even the "low quality" imagery wouldn't hide one.

This example may be a helpful to reminder for all of us  to occasionally read/reread Bellingcat's " OSHIT: Seven Deadly Sins of Bad Open Source Research" [(link)](https://www.bellingcat.com/resources/2024/04/25/oshit-seven-deadly-sins-of-bad-open-source-research/) 

> **5. Incorrectly Using Tools and Interpreting Data**
> There are many different open source tools out there, and we even try to keep a list of useful resources in Bellingcat‚Äôs Online Investigation Toolkit. However, as with any new tool, users often need some guidance, experience and training to master it.
> 
> We often see new users not being aware of these tools‚Äô limitations. New tools aren‚Äôt silver bullets and they often come with many caveats.

The glossary is not intended to be exhaustive. We have focused on some of the most common symbols used in transnational contexts, as well as some symbols that may be less well-known outside specific national, regional and/or cultural contexts, but that are still associated with significant hate activity and useful to researchers. 
These symbols should always be identified and evaluated in context, since many in this glossary may appear in non-hateful contexts or resemble other symbols.

As the person who handled the NED grant back when I was at Bellingcat, it had a quite narrow reach.  It funded our Russian-language workshops for a few years and covered some staff salary costs related to that. It was pretty cloistered off on its own compared to the rest of the organization. Eventually it got too annoying dealing with all the questions about NED, and our workshops had trained just about every Russian-speaking researcher/journalists I could find who wanted to use OSINT in their work, so we wound that down and didn't apply for a renewal of our grant. I don't have the numbers in front of me, and have forgotten them, but I don't think NED money ever made up more than a quarter of the entire organization's funding (again, I'm just remembering this off the top of my head). NED was incredibly hands-off in their funding and we got to do basically what we wanted to -- giving what is our normal training workshops (which normally cost $2k+ to attend) in-person, for free, in my godawful Russian, to Russian-speaking journalists + researchers. They didn't provide 'core funding' like some other grants/donations did. anyways, if you have pent up anger and hatred towards bellingcat around NED funding, direct it at me, I was writing the annual reports and doing the applications.

(Sorry for humoring him <@527611127576920075>, I just get annoyed from all the NED conspiracies, when really it was all quite  understated compared to the public attention it's gotten)

and yes the reason why there were no annual reports pre-2019 is because we (i say we in the past tense, i'm not bellingcat anymore! just in spirit.) spent all our team doing research/writing/training and barely chugging along when it came to money/financial administration hahaha. when we hired our business director in 2019 everything became much, much more professional/organized.

Long story short, Niantic split the Ingress and Pokemon Go maps due to the sale of the latter in the last few years. üëãüèº Based on recent discussions over in <#1018196475932590090> , I'd like to recommend two excellent culinary resources. Both of these are expert-level resources and industry standards. They are *not* cookbooks; they are research books.

**"The Food Lover's Companion"** - Essentially a quick-reference guide to many ingredients and preparations.
https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6175841-the-deluxe-food-lover-s-companion

**"On Food And Cooking"** - This is a masterwork of science and food. It delves much deeper into specifics of biology, chemistry, physics, and food history to help us understand what we're eating, and how and why. At one point, this text was required reading in the Culinary Institute of America's curriculum.

I'm Radim, a dev currently living in Dubai. For the past few years, I‚Äôve been pretty much obsessed with the technical side of digital forensics‚Äîespecially the "gaslighting" problem we all see in OSINT when key evidence just vanishes or gets quietly edited.

My focus is on building "Proof of Existence" systems. Lately, I've been experimenting with ways to anchor full forensic captures (including the DOM and metadata) to the blockchain. I want to see if we can create a truly tamper-proof chain of custody that even works behind paywalls.

I‚Äôm mostly here to listen and soak up your methodologies. I want to make sure the tech I‚Äôm building actually supports high-standard investigations instead of just adding noise.

Looking forward to learning from you all!

The stretch is approx. 500 m long, which would be enough for a Russian submarine. Their lengths range from 107 - 184 m. As for the water depth, there appear to be no publicly available charts with finer detail. However, the entire area seems to offer sufficient depths (ranging from 100 to 500 m) for an approach, even in icy conditions.
Besides that, the area appears to be a known combat training area for fleet exercises and the primary testing ground for nuclear submarines (Yasen-Ma and Borei-M classes built at Sevmash shipyard). There appear to be regular warnings for the NAVAREA XX region. The only site I've found to actually cover NAVAREA XX is: https://nsr.rosatom.ru/en/navigational-and-weather-information/navarea/
There's also more information on activities on page 16 of the Polar Vortex Defence Report from April 2025. 
https://defencereport.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/Polar-Vortex-The-Strategic-Importance-of-Russias-Northern-Sea-Route-DefenceReport.pdf
It highlights the importance of the area also for the Northern Sea Route and for 'acoustic shielding' of submarines for which the area appears to be perfect.
There are also reports on an Arctic sensor grid called 'Harmony' built by Russia to monitor the ares: https://www.armyrecognition.com/news/navy-news/2025/russia-built-secret-arctic-sensor-grid-to-shield-nuclear-submarines-using-u-s-and-eu-technology and https://www.icij.org/investigations/russia-archive/russia-secretly-acquired-western-technology-to-protect-its-nuclear-submarine-fleet/

But I still want to give you a community-oriented response: This isn't the kind of research we usually assist with. While Bellingcat is an 'open-source-first' outlet/community, we usually try to keep the focus really on issues that are journalistic in nature. There are other (OSINT) communities that will be more receptive to requests that relate to finding individuals. I assume your request is genuine, but apart from  <#710991734246473809> and https://www.bellingcat.com/about/editorial-standards-practices/ it's just not 'our thing' if you know what I mean.

There are other communities that focus on this kind of work, and while I don't know whether or not they will allow you to post the information you have (my guess is that it's unlikely), they will probably be more experienced with things like data minimization, opsec, etc. (Prefer those that have a formal intake and handoff process.) You could try TraceLabs.org, locate.international, or osint.uk, maybe KASE, doenetwork.org, websleuths.com, or the gratefuldoe subreddit. 

That being said, my advice would be to 
a) as a good general rule - never post screenshots/photos from a phone that's not yours. 
b) Hand the phone in **where it was first found**. This is where the owner will check first. Lost and found, local police, municipal lost-property service. (Also, that's required by law in most jurisdictions anyway.)
c) Keep it charged so that Apple's intended recovery channel has a chance to work.

Good luck!

The political implications are very difficult to gauge at the moment. There is a great degree of public outrage (https://discord.com/channels/709752884257882135/709946606144847872/1449709209515069522), but with a very close election coming in April, everyone in the government and government media is scrambling to manage public opinion and either try to sweep this under the rug, or control the narrative through anything ranging from new appointments to lead child care institutions to astounding degrees of victim blaming.
There hasn't been comprehensive polling data published since the two major reports came out, so I don't really know more than that. Plus I mostly exist in Budapest, which is a bit of a progressive/liberal bubble, so the attitude here is likely not entirely representative of how the country as a whole is reacting to the issue.

As for the 90% of cases pursued having been dismissed, it's not clear to me how many of these were dismissed maliciously, or due to a lack of specialised personnel who could support the investigation. I think it was even mentioned in one of the above reports that many of the victims had to wait 9+ months after reporting abuse for a specialised psychologist to talk to them, at which point authorities usually claimed that the incidents happened too long ago to reasonably investigate.

Yes, it's an appropriate question for this thread. Although part of it would fit in data-science as well. Your question essentially has two parts, right?
First, you want to know about the tools to get the data, and maybe visualize it. 

I use Apify and Octoparse for X analysis. They're not free, but pretty cheap for what they offer. They use the advanced search function. Apify in particular is worth the money (although Octoparse delivered somewhat better results for some reason in my testing - about 30% more tweets returned in some specific cases). 
You can make requests from your home computer automatically using python and JSON.  

You can also use free solutions using puppeteer and selenium, or if you prefer something more manual, I would point you in the direction of https://bellingcat.gitbook.io/toolkit/more/all-tools/zeeschuimer

For visualization, you could go any number of routes, depending on your question. Gephi is infamous, Maltego is very manual but I love it, and then you could go any number of ways to  visualize more complicated graph data models...

But what exactly do you mean by "cataloguing networks"? (That's the data science part.)

Thank you to the mods for allowing me to post this ‚ù§Ô∏è 
(I have marked all images with numbers, so that is what I am referencing below.)
The Challenge: I wanted to test the model's ability to handle "void" environments, specifically generic desert highways with zero signage or distinct landmarks (see Image 1).

The AI Lead: Instead of hallucinating a random desert in Nevada or UAE, the model correctly identified the specific "semi-arid" vegetation and road infrastructure style of Central Kazakhstan.

Prediction: Kyzylorda Region, Kazakhstan (70% Confidence) (see Image 2).

Result: It placed the pin on the correct highway (M32/E38).

Verification & Accuracy: The estimate was ~133km off from the actual coordinates, but crucially, it placed me on the correct road corridor (see Image 3).

Verdict: It didn't give the exact mile marker, but it successfully narrowed down a continent-sized search area to a single highway stretch. For a "zero metadata" image, I consider this a solid starting point for manual verification.

Location used for the challenge: https://maps.app.goo.gl/4GUhbjLD8278ArYq5
My model predicted: Unknown, Kazakhstan, 45.0000¬∞, 65.0000¬∞ with a 25 km error radius. (Note: I know the coordinates seem weirdly perfect, but I promise this is a coincidence. Try the model yourself to see how it normally guesses.)

Try the tool (Free/No Login): https://www.geolocator.app/demo (Feedback on my version 3's accuracy is welcome)

You're welcome. On the technical side, it uses a model based on CLIP, which gives it general knowledge of things and what they look like, and its ability to "understand" text and images, and then it's fine-tuned on aerial imagery plus OpenStreetMap data, so it learns about infrastructure and things that people put on maps and what they look like from above.

I've been working on a geospatial/aerial imagery semantic search tool for a while. The idea started in 2010 but it was only recently that the tech has become available to implement it in a useful way. It offers a way to do a wide variety of, even ad hoc semantic queries over large datasets very quickly. You want to look for cars? Enter "cars". Cars near water? Just type that in. Similarly for mines, roads, solar panels, police cars, aircraft boneyards. Red buildings with "Iran Air Cargo" painted on the roof? type it in. It's multi-modal, so you can also query with images. Have an aerial image of an S-200 site and you want to find more? Upload it. That last one is actually in the demo video, which shows off some of the capabilities: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EjH0kMEz4YY

It's not better than a custom model for identifying any particular thing, but it does a good job of identifying a huge variety of things, and it's very fast.

üëä We've just shared a short investigation into a far-right fight night that happened in California at the end of August.
Far-right fight nights are events bringing together combat fighting, extremist bands and merch, in an attempt to bring in new recruits and solidify existing relationships. Researcher <@975351092986658846> locates the latest event for a California-based far-right group: https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2025/09/15/active-club-fight-night-2025-san-diego/?utm_source=discord 
Although the organising groups publicise their operations to their followers, owners of the venues used for these events are often unaware of what is happening behind closed doors or who the organisers really are. Sadly, in this case, an event owner was duped and told it was a booking to film a commercial for an activewear brand. 

If you want to look further into these networks and how they operate, check out <#813082873862160384>

How do you monitor a conflict in a region that is difficult to access and rife with misinformation claims? Nothing is permanent on social media. Users deleting their posts or webpages can lead to the erasure of a trail of evidence that may be crucial to your investigations. But how do you keep that vital data? We've improved our Auto Archiver tool to make archiving your sources easier and set it up to be more manageable to navigate as a research team... https://www.bellingcat.com/resources/2025/08/13/the-open-source-tool-that-has-preserved-150000-pieces-of-online-evidence/?utm_source=discord 

Launched publicly in 2022, our Auto Archiver tool has helped newsrooms and NGO‚Äôs preserve over 150,000 web pages and social media posts to date. It is a staple in our newsroom. 
If you work in a newsroom or research team and want to access a demo or help to deploy the Auto Archiver internally you can reach us at contact-tech@bellingcat.com with the Subject ‚ÄúAuto Archiver at [my team/organisation]‚Äù and tell us more about your organisation and archiving needs.

Of course no tool is perfect and we‚Äôre looking for feedback, if you have suggestions for the tool please reach out via an issue in our GitHub: https://github.com/bellingcat/auto-archiver

I value safety over transparency when having to make a decision between the two, and I assess this often.

A new report by Bellingcat‚Äôs Justice & Accountability (J&A) Unit and the Global Legal Action Network (GLAN - Global Legal Action Network) detailing the use of cluster munitions in civilian areas in Kharkiv at the beginning of the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine is published today. The report is based on 32 in-depth investigations of separate incidents that took place between February and April 2022. It offers one of the most detailed looks yet at the use of cluster munitions against civilian areas, a practice that raises serious questions regarding violations of International Humanitarian Law.  https://j-and-a.glanlaw.org/kharkiv

Bellingcat‚Äôs J&A Unit helped build mechanisms for open source research to enhance legal accountability processes, particularly in cases of atrocity crimes. This report signifies the last piece of research that will be conducted by Bellingcat as part of this team.

GLAN is continuing its OSI accountability work, and you can find out more about that and any legacy J&A projects here: https://j-and-a.glanlaw.org/

Working with our partners Evident and CalMatters we have monitored the LA raids, discovering recurring trends and tactics used by officers. 
We collected videos of more than 100 incidents of arrest between June 6 and June 30 in Los Angeles and the immediate surrounding areas. We all know AI models can now create realistic images and videos but how do they fare at identifying where a real image was taken? Bellingcat researchers have put large language models to the test; we ran 500 geolocation tests, with 20 models each analysing the same set of 25 images. A wealthy sportsman and oil tycoon was shot on the driveway of his Corpus Christi, Texas home by two gunmen in waiting. Despite witnesses, no one was convicted for the murder.

A January operation in the central Californian city of Bakersfield saw dozens detained by US border patrol agents operating more than 300 miles from the US southern border. On Thursday, the fantastic people behind the Open Source Munitions Portal (OSMP) will be joining us for a Stage Talk. The free-to-use tool aims to provide a key resource to democratise information about conflict and open up access to understanding munitions use.
They offer nearly 1000 reference images of a variety of munitions from active conflict zones, each reviewed and assessed by at least two munitions experts. Key information is provided about each image, including reported location, tentative model of munition and, where relevant, analyst notes written by experts at ARES. They've also got guides to key munition types, explainer videos, and a simple glossary of key terms on there. Recently the team launched the first of a series of articles using 3D interactive models to explain how to identify some of the most widely used munitions - including linking these models to relevant images from the archive. In the talk we'll be discussing all of these features and taking your questions on identification of munitions, so come with some prepped! Find us in the Stage area on Thursday at 12pm EDT/5pm CET.

Adverts selling Nitazenes, an opioid up to 500 times stronger than heroin, are all over the internet, from social media platforms to trade sites. Yeah something on this too, while researching criminal organizations themselves (outside actual cyber groups) may come with "lesser" physical risks, there's absolutely still issues of their own to focus on that could go sideways. It's why with actual OPSEC you assess based upon operational specifics, not just a broad "do this".
One thing I do and advise heavily when covering that angle, if you are ever having to deal with pictures and social profiles, do not ever use photos of people with their children, that is how you can cross a red line that probably wouldn't be thought of. There's nearly always other pics to use also, so, it is kinda just good practice not to use those. Do not post about their homes or vehicle license plates either, you might think that's fine - that could get them and their family killed while out to eat breakfast on Sunday (their respective adversaries look at all this stuff if they can to harm them too, just, physically instead of article exposes).

We‚Äôre back with more detail on 1xBet‚Äôs amateur sport gambling model, thanks to members of our Discord community who have found the locations of 10+  games that are broadcast to the betting site...  https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2024/11/19/volunteers-find-1xbet-stream-sites/?utm_source=discord 


We recently shared how the controversial Russian-founded gambling platform 1xBet is taking bets on thousands of amateur sports events live-streamed to its website from secret locations. Previously we examined hundreds of videos broadcast to 1xBet and initially geolocated six venues in three countries. They included a children's football school in Russia, a basketball arena in Belarus, and a sports hall in Ukraine's capital city. Now our community has found more than 10 new sites which host football, basketball, ice hockey and cricket tournaments broadcasted to 1xBet around the clock. Idea - FEMA related disinformation and Hurricane Milton and Helene. Disinformation during weather events has always been a thing (I can tell you more about the rumors of levee bombing during Katrina), but in particular, the massive push this time of FEMA disinformation as a US election issue.
Points, as I have my coffee:
- FEMA is a federal agency and current disinformation pushers dream of dismantling as many federal agencies as possible
- Low information in US areas that aren't normally impacted by hurricanes: people may say "FEMA is only giving x" while not understanding that state level programs, personal insurance, local services, etc, are filling in other gaps. It is indeed a patchwork 
- Lack of working tech infrastructure can lead to the fallback of old telephone-style networks, where word passes around by mouth

Welcome to the Bellingcat Discord! On behalf of the team, we appreciate you joining. 

**Below are some tips and pointers to help guide you through the server:**

1.  Always keep in mind that **this is an open server.** That means that absolutely anyone can join, including bad actors. That means that there are bad actors in this server, watching. So, never share anything on here that you wouldn't want the entire world to know about, including bad people. 

2. Bellingcat does not endorse any project or initiative by any member(s) of this server unless otherwise explicitly stated by Bellingcat. 

3. Whether you‚Äôre an open source research professional or just getting started, there‚Äôs a place for you on this server. We encourage you to ask questions and get involved in conversations. Don‚Äôt be shy! Here is a Google Doc with some introductory resources: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1MuV_NeZ0FiQNJbPkx7jwMgntjGcRKFF1MoCZhJ7G_-Y/edit?usp=sharing

4. If you're new to the server, we recommend that you lurk for a few days to get a feel for the place. That way, when you're ready to post, you'll fit right in!

5. Some channels (like the one dedicated to the invasion of Ukraine) may contain graphic content. In order to view these channels, you must first visit <#1023777114262093855> and click the ‚ÄúI agree to view sensitive media‚Äù, if you so choose. 

6. If you‚Äôd like, you can introduce yourself to your fellow server members in the <#966599459754618930> channel. Feel free to share anything you‚Äôd like about yourself, like what your research interests are or what open source skills you‚Äôd like to develop.

7. If you have any questions, comments or concerns about the server, please send a message to <@575252669443211264>. 

8. If your Discord nickname is inappropriate for the tone and vibe of our community (for example, if it references graphic sexual acts/organs/fluids), or if it contains invalid characters, you will get a new nickname free of charge courtesy of the Wu-Tang Clan Name Generator! If your profile contains inappropriate content, you'll be kicked from the server and invited to re-join after you've edited your server profile accordingly.

9. We have an agreement with the other big open source servers (Project Owl, Kase, OSINTION, and Trace Labs) to crossban across our servers. That means that if you're banned in our server, you may also be banned in those other servers and vice versa.

10. The opinions expressed here by Bellingcat staff are their own and don't necessarily represent Bellingcat's official opinions.

The purpose of these rules is not only to adhere to Discord's Community Guidelines, but also to help foster a community where you can feel welcomed to learn from others and make meaningful contributions. We want your experience in this server to be an example of the principles and values that we at Bellingcat hold, including collaboration, tenacity, diversity, ingenuity, and integrity. 

The server rules are:

**1. Treat everyone with respect.** Absolutely no harassment, witch hunting, sexism, racism, or hate speech will be tolerated.
     A. This includes our Server Moderators. The moderating team is made up   of dedicated volunteers who want you  to have a good experience here. Please treat them with respect. 

**2. Sharing links or images that contain graphic content for its own sake is strictly not allowed.** There must be an academic, journalistic, and/or research-related reason for sharing this type of content. When sharing news articles, tweets, or other news media that may contain violence or graphic content, you must spoiler tag it (/spoiler), and you must describe the nature of the content to avoid people from clicking on it accidentally. 
    A. Do not post content that shows gore or uncensored dead bodies. 
    B. If you must share a graphic image for geolocation, use an image editor (like MS Paint) to remove the graphic content.
    C. If you're not sure about any of the above, DM a <@575252669443211264> .

**3. Do not post anything that violates Discord's Community Guidelines.** As a Discord user you should be familiar with the Community Guidelines, which can be found here: https://discord.com/guidelines

**4. This is not a server for debating politics/religions/economics/etc.** As a Bellingcat community hub, the purpose of this server is to learn about open source research, and share and analyze news. If you want to debate your opinions, please keep it in DMs. 
A. Occasionally, the moderating team will ask server members to refrain from engaging with certain emerging topics. This will usually be the case with topics that require a high level of technical, scholarly or insider knowledge that the server lacks. Whenever we make a request to refrain from engaging with a topic, we will post an explanation in ‚Å†<#924344679812726797>.

**5. No spam or self-promotion (server invites, advertisements, etc.) without permission from a staff member or server moderator.** This includes DMing fellow members. When in doubt, please DM a staff member. We'll almost always say "yes!" to your request.
A. Sharing crowdsourcing campaigns for money is not allowed in this server.
B. Advertising paid services or products is not allowed in this server. 
C. Please don't advertise your services. If you're looking for work, check for postings in <#709760136222212127>.

**6. Absolutely no doxxing (sharing people's personal information) of any kind.**
A. Please do not ask anyone in this server to help you find a person's home address, phone number, email addresses, social media profiles, or anything to that effect. This is  an open server, and we have no way of knowing what your intentions are. 
B. If you are a journalist working on a project and you need help doing this, feel message <@&1212114000020643860> to get moderator permission to post your request. 
C. Don't accuse random people of being bots/malfeasance. 

7. **Articles which contain a description of sexual violence can only be shared in https://discord.com/channels/709752884257882135/1118448280435687506.** Articles that simply mention that sexual violence has occurred as part of a broader conflict may be placed in appropriate regional or other channels. Breaking this rule will result in an automatic one-week timeout. If you're unsure as to where you can share an article, please message <@575252669443211264> to ask for clarification.
